Keywords: Automotive, Computers And Peripherals, Consumer Electronics & Appliances, ICs, Internet Of Things, Labor & Worker Relations, Market Research, Medical Devices & Systems, Outsourcing, Semiconductor Design & Manufacturing, Semiconductors, Transportation
Article: SAN FRANCISCO â Semiconductor industry analysts and market watchers expressed concern after U.S. President Donald Trump announced that the U.S. would impose 25% tariffs on $50 billion of Chinese goods, including many products in the semiconductor supply chain. U.S. chip firms and their suppliers largely oppose the tariffs and the escalation of a trade war between the worldâs two largest economies. The ultimate result, many fear, will be decreased sales of electronic products and components. The Trump administration has argued that the tariffs are necessary to close a $375 billion trade deficit with China and counter Chinese policies deemed harmful to U.S. industry, including required technology transfers and lax intellectual-property protection. The SEMI trade group, which represents semiconductor equipment suppliers, EDA vendors, and companies involved in the electronics supply chain, has voiced support for the administrationâs efforts to protect intellectual property, but said that it does not believe the tariffs will do anything to address U.S. concerns over Chinaâs trade practices. In a blog posted on the SEMI website on Friday (June 15), Jay Chittooran, a public policy manager at SEMI, said that about 80% of the semiconductor products that appeared on the list of products that was first proposed for tariffs by the U.S. Trade Representative back in April remain on the list, including products such as test inspection equipment and spare parts that enter the U.S. from China.                    Will the tariffs imposed by the Trump Administrative on Chinese products be a net positive or negative for U.S. high-tech workers?          Yes! The tariffs imposed by the Trump Administration will cause consumers to buy more U.S.-made products, ultimately leading to more U.S. jobs in tech manufacturing and elsewhere in the supply chain.        No. The tariffs imposed by the Trump Administration will be a drag on sales of U.S. technology components and other products, ultimately hurting U.S. high-tech salaries and leading to job cuts.        Neither. The tariffs will have no impact on U.S. tech jobs one way or the other.
